0.title: About this blog
0.content: . Hello, this is Mandy’s blog. I am a software engineer, graphic designer, illustrator and musician. This Jekyll blog was started to: . | make my README prettier | post my vegan recipes | migrate my gists to a structured, searchable place | more to come! | .

1.title: Why Jekyll?
1.content: There are many CMS options such as WordPress, Squarespace, Wix, and cooler features if I used React, Laraval or Ruby and Rails. Why Jekyll? . | Static sites are blazing fast | Easy fast and free to deploy | A bunch of documentation and prior discussion | Ruby is a joy to use | . Current build and deployment times are about 1 minute each for a 2 minute pipeline.

2.title: About this Theme
2.content: This is the base Jekyll theme. You can find out more info about customizing your Jekyll theme, as well as basic Jekyll usage documentation at jekyllrb.com . | Just the Docs at GitHub: just-the-docs / just-the-docs | Jekyll at GitHub: jekyll / jekyll | Mandy’s custom theme at GitHub: picaq / picaq.github.io / _sass/custom/custom.scss | Switchable dark/light theme solution thanks to @Teddy-van-Jerry Theme Switching Button · Issue #1223 · just-the-docs/just-the-docs | .

5.title: Bookmarklets
5.content: Most javascript I write are in the form of bookmarklets. Here is its structure: . javascript: (()=>{ console.log("some code here"); })(); . Here is how to use one .

6.title: Formatting
6.content: Compared to normal javascript, a finished bookmarklet is similar to minified js with all extraneous whitespace characters removed. Therefore, a finished bookmarklet: . | must not contain comments | all lines must end with semi-colons, even after a closing curly bracket } | new-lines, even in constants and in template strings, are interpreted differently so the use of \n is preferred | it is best to have a readable formatted bookmarklet in addition to the finished minified version | .

7.title: Caramelized Miso Carrots
7.content: . This is Oil-Free! . The ingredients are exteremely basic but for safety, there is an absolutely necessary long wait for the cooking vessel to cool down. Do NOT peek at the food while cooking! .

8.title: Ingredients
8.content: . | 1 cup carrot sticks or carrots chunks | tamari | slivered onions ( optional ) | miso paste ( optional ) | .

9.title: Instructions
9.content: . | Add carrots and tamari ( to taste ) to a large ceramic bowl. If desired, add onions. Add a splash of water if the ingredients seem dry. | Cover the top of a bowl with a wider, overturned ceramic bowl or plate. | Microwave the carrot bowls for: . | 3 minutes on the highest power, | followed by 2 minutes at 30% power | and finally, 22 minutes on the lowest power setting. | . | Let sit to cool for 15 – 40 minutes before attempting to retrieve or look at the food. DO NOT TOUCH the ceramic bowls until cooling time has elapsed!! | Optional: after cooling, stir in a tsp of miso paste for extra umami. | . The carrots should look bruised and wrinkly in appearance, sometimes with dark spots, but taste sweet, caramelized and savory. The texture is extremely soft and melts in your mouth. It can be refrigerated for a week or two.

10.title: Serving Options
10.content: . | You can use this as a side dish or eat it as-is. | It is a good sandwich or wrap ingredient, goes well with soups, peas or as an accompaniment. | After chilling them in the fridge, they can be added to salads or bentos. | .

11.title: Why not use an instant pot or pressure cooker?
11.content: I don’t have one, and I don’t want to clean a specialized large, separate cooking vessel. If you were able to successfully replicate this recipe using those appliances let me know! .

12.title: Cheese et Cetera
12.content: I used to have a really bad cheese addiction. I like yogurt too. Trying not to clog my arteries over here! . The tables below compare the saturated fat content by grams/serving as well as by % weight of the tastiest fermented non-dairy dairy alternatives ( that I’ve tried so far ). Not included are those that I didn’t like. Coconut oil is the absolute bane of my existence.

25.title: Dairy Free Milks
25.content: I recently bought a soy milk maker, which is basically a stainless steel blender with a heating element. It has 6 pre-programmed sequences. Here are the included recipes in the manual in case I can’t find it. | Dairy Free Milks . | Basic Formula . | Ingredients | Instructions | Nut Milks . | Almond Milk | Cashew Milk | Coconut Milk | Walnut Milk | Hazelnut Milk | Hemp Milk | Almond Peanut Milk | . | Bean Milk . | Soy Milk | Oat Soy Milk | Walnut Oat Soy Milk | . | Grain Milks . | Oat Milk | Rice Milk | Oat Rice Paste | . | Juice . | Apple Pineapple Juice | Carrot Honey Juice | . | Yogurt . | Carb Content | Yogurt Instructions | . | . | Machine specifications . | Pre-programmed functions | . | . | .

26.title: Basic Formula
26.content: The milk making process follow the same basic formula and instuctions. The only things you need are the ( a ) main ingredient(s): food, and water ( e ). Sweeterners and flavorings ( b – d ) are optional.

27.title: Ingredients
27.content: . | nuts, soy or fruit | sweetener | spices or flavorings | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

28.title: Instructions
28.content: . | Add ingredients ( a – d ) into the milk maker. | Add water ( e ) above the min but below the max water line. | Press function button ( 10 – 35 minutes ). | Unplug the power cord before pouring out the liquid. | Optionally: strain the milk in a strainer or nut bag. | .

30.title: Almond Milk
30.content: . | 60 g raw almonds | 4 – 5 pitted dates | 2 tsp vanilla extract pinch of ground cinnamon | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

31.title: Cashew Milk
31.content: . | 60 g raw cashews | 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

32.title: Coconut Milk
32.content: . | 60 g shredded coconut meat | 5 – 6 pitted dates | vanilla pod | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

33.title: Walnut Milk
33.content: . | 60 g walnuts | 4 – 5 tsp allulose syrup | 5 – 6 pitted dates | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

34.title: Hazelnut Milk
34.content: . | 60 g hazelnuts | 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

35.title: Hemp Milk
35.content: . | 60 g hulled hemp seeds | 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract 6 – 7 pitted medjool dates | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

36.title: Almond Peanut Milk
36.content: . | 40 g almonds 20 g cooked peanuts | sugar | 2 tsp vanilla extract 6 – 7 pitted medjool dates | dash of salt | oat milk ( just under 1 liter ) | .

37.title: Bean Milk
37.content: Beans : 35 minutes . For creamier soy milk, it is best to rinse and then warm soak the beans for a few hours, preferably overnight, and then rinse again before blending. Before serving, the soy milk foam should be skimmed off the surface.

38.title: Soy Milk
38.content: . | 60 g soybeans | 3 medjool dates 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

39.title: Oat Soy Milk
39.content: . | 35 g soybeans 15 g instant oats | sugar to taste | 10 g toasted black sesame seeds | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

40.title: Walnut Oat Soy Milk
40.content: . | 40 g soybeans 10 g oats 10 g walnut (~ 1 whole walnut) | ? | ? | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

42.title: Oat Milk
42.content: . | 60 g rolled oats | 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

43.title: Rice Milk
43.content: . | 60 g rice | 3 – 4 tsp maple syrup | 2 tsp vanilla extract and/or 2 tbsp cacao powder | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

44.title: Oat Rice Paste
44.content: . | 12 g each of: . | rice | oats | soy beans | red dates | pine nuts | . | dash of salt | water ( just under 1 liter ) | .

46.title: Apple Pineapple Juice

47.title: Carrot Honey Juice
47.content: . | 200 g carrot | 170 g apple | 20 ml allulose syrup | any of the above milks ( just under 1 liter ) | .

62.title: Gists
62.content: My code snippets are hosted on GitHub’s Gists. I plan to move them here eventually.

64.title: Ingredients
64.content: . | Sriracha ( or your favorite hot sauce ) | peanut butter | sliced bread of choice | basil ( highly recomended but optional ) | tamari ( optional ) | baby spinach ( optional ) | .

65.title: Instructions
65.content: . | Toast slice(s) of bread ( optional but recommended ). | Make the spread: mix peanut butter and Sriracha together, adjust ratios to taste and tolerance. Optional: add tamari for saltiness or to thin out the spread. | Spread the mixture on the inside-facing sides of the bread slice(s). | Optional: top with 1 – 2 basil leaves and/or baby spinach. | .

66.title: Serving Options
66.content: . | Using a single slice of toasted bread would make this a Hot Sauce Toast. | You can turn this into a sandwich by clamping 2+ toasts together. | I also like spreading a bit garlic achaar or harissa sauce on top for extra flavor depth. | With the breads subbed for rice paper, veggies doubled and spread halved, the contents could be made into a Vietnamese spring roll. | .

68.title: JavaScript
68.content: Most javascript I write are either in the form of bookmarklets or ran directly in the console.

69.title: Math & Number Manipulations
69.content: . | Math & Number Manipulations . | Arithmatic . | factorial | factorial big int | product | split num into arr of digits | sum | randomize | print natural countdown in the console | . | Time conversions . | convert HHMMSS to seconds | convert seconds To HHMMSS | . | Phone Number format . | digits to phone number format and back | . | Currency conversions | Binary & Ascii math . | ascii | integer to binary and back | xor encryption to hex and back | . | . | .

71.title: factorial
71.content: const bang = n => { if ( n < 2 ) return 1; let fact = 1, i = 2; while (i <= n) {fact*=i; i++}; return fact; } .

72.title: factorial big int
72.content: const bigBang = n => { if ( n < 2n ) return 1n; let fact = 1n, i = 2n; while (i <= n) {fact*=i; i++}; return fact; } .

74.title: split num into arr of digits
74.content: const digitize = int => { let number = parseInt(int); let sum = 10; let arr = []; while (number > 0) { val = number % 10; sum += val; arr.push(val); number = (number - val) / 10; } console.log(sum); return arr.reverse(); } .

75.title: sum
75.content: arr.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0); // slow, iterative sum of 1 + 2 + 3 ... + n of known n O(n) const sum = (n) => { let val = 0; while (n > 0) { val += n; n--; } return val; } // faster calculation O(1) const sum2 = n => n * (n + 1)/2; .

77.title: print natural countdown in the console

78.title: Time conversions
78.content: Convert hh:mm:ss to seconds and back + number formats .

79.title: convert HHMMSS to seconds
79.content: const toSec = str => str.split(':').reduce((a, time) => (60 * a) + +time); .

80.title: convert seconds To HHMMSS
80.content: const toHMS = totalSec => { const hours = Math.floor((totalSec % (60 * 60 * 24)) / (60 * 60)); const minutes = Math.floor((totalSec % (60 * 60)) / (60)); const seconds = Math.floor((totalSec % (60)) ); // removes all leading zeros const hhmmss = `${ hours > 0 ? hours + ":" : "" }${ hours > 0 && minutes < 10 ? '0' + minutes : minutes }:${ seconds < 10 ? '0' + seconds : seconds }`; // keeps all leading zeros const _0_HMS = `${ hours < 10 ? '0' + hours : hours }:${ minutes < 10 ? '0' + minutes : minutes }:${ seconds < 10 ? '0' + seconds : seconds }`; return _0_HMS; } .

82.title: digits to phone number format and back
82.content: const formatPhone = digts => `(${digts.slice(0,3)}) ${digts.slice(3,6)}-${digts.slice(-4)}`; const phoneToNumString = phone => phone.match(/\d/g).join(""); .

83.title: Currency conversions
83.content: This is based off of this freecodecamp guide: How to Format a Number as Currency in JavaScript . currency.js . // format number to US dollar let usd = new Intl.NumberFormat('en-US', { style: 'currency', currency: 'USD', }); let cad = new Intl.NumberFormat('en-CA', { style: 'currency', currency: 'CAD', }); // format number to British pounds let pounds = Intl.NumberFormat('en-GB', { style: 'currency', currency: 'GBP', }); // format number to Indian rupee let rupee = new Intl.NumberFormat('en-IN', { style: 'currency', currency: 'INR', }); // format number to Euro let euro = Intl.NumberFormat('en-DE', { style: 'currency', currency: 'EUR', }); // format number to yuan let yuan = Intl.NumberFormat('cn-CN', { style: 'currency', currency: 'CNY', }); // format number to yen let yen = Intl.NumberFormat('jp-JA', { style: 'currency', currency: 'JPY', }); // format number to won let won = Intl.NumberFormat('kr-KR', { style: 'currency', currency: 'KRW', }); 'Dollars: ' + USDollar.format(price) // Dollars: $143,450.00 `Pounds: ${pounds.format(price)}`; // Pounds: £143,450.00 'Rupees: ' + rupee.format(price); // Rupees: ₹1,43,450.00 `Euro: ${euro.format(price)}`; // Euro: €143,450.00 .

85.title: ascii
85.content: a.charCodeAt(0); // get char code int from str char String.fromCharCode(...nums); // convert list of nums to string // convert string to arr of char code nums const charCodes = (string) => { let nums = []; for (i in string) nums.push(string.charCodeAt(i)); return nums; } // convert hex to string const hex2str = (hex) => { let outputNums = []; for (let i = 0; i < hex.length; i+=2) { const int = parseInt(hex[i+0] + hex[i+1], 16); outputNums.push(int); } return String.fromCharCode(...outputNums); } // convert string to hex const str2hex = (string) => { hex = ""; for (i in string) hex += string.charCodeAt(i).toString("16").padStart(2, '0'); return hex; } .

86.title: integer to binary and back
86.content: const intBin = int => int.toString(2); // must be called as a function to work otherwise it will error const binInt = bin => parseInt(bin, 2); const intHex = int => int.toString(16); // must be called as a function to work otherwise it will error const hexInt = hex => parseInt(hex, 16); .

87.title: xor encryption to hex and back
87.content: const xor2hex = (input, key) => { let output = ""; const len = key.length; const toXorHex = (a, b) => (a ^ b).toString("16").padStart(2, '0'); for (i in input) { output += toXorHex(input.charCodeAt(i), key.charCodeAt(i % len)); }; return output; } const hex2xor = (input, key) => { let outputNums = []; const len = key.length; for (let i = 0; i < input.length; i+=2) { const int = parseInt(input[i+0] + input[i+1], 16); outputNums.push(int ^ key.charCodeAt(i/2 % len)); } return String.fromCharCode(...outputNums); } .

89.title: Mushroom [ Ghost Pepper ] Marinara Dal
89.content: I usually meal prep this in a mason jar or two and eat it over the course of 1 – 3 weeks.

90.title: Ingredients
90.content: Everything after water is optional and added to taste. | 1 cup red lentils | 1 jar of marinara sauce | kombu dashi or water | 1 cup sliced mushrooms | tomato paste | ghost pepper hot sauce | vegan ponzu | tamari | pepper powder | .

91.title: Instructions
91.content: . | Rinse and strain the lentils until the water runs clear. It usually takes me 4 – 7 rinses. | Boil the lentils in 3 cups of water ( 2 if adding mushrooms ) for 10 – 20 minutes depending on desired tenderness. | Stir in the marinara sauce and adjust to taste with the rest of the ingredients. | Optional: re-boil the dal mixture for the flavors to meld together even more. | . I would use the original marinara sauce jar as well as the mason jar used to rinse and cook the lentils to store leftovers in the fridge for up to 3 weeks.

92.title: Serving Options
92.content: I usually eat this with: . | a slice or two of steamed sourdough bread ( because I don’t know how to make idli and this is close enough for me lol ) | steamed organic green peas | pita chips | naan | .

104.title: How does it compare to regular nacho cheese?
104.content: . | creamy and slightly sticky just like real nacho cheese | you can customize the level of umami | doesn’t dry out quickly like nacho cheese, where the cheese requires heating to stay melted and the roux dries out and hardens as water evaporates | high protein, low-carb and somewhat low fat | far less oily: the primary source of oil is from the cashew butter | less filler ( flour/roux/starch, sodium citrate ) means more flavor | can be eaten at room temperature, warmed or chilled | .

119.title: Kalimba tabs?
119.content: I get asked this sometimes but I prefer transcribing music into staff notation due to being instrument-agnostic and its ease to adapt to other instruments. In the near future I will sort sheet music by chromatic range rather than by instrument.
